Writing Effective Tools for Agents — with Agents

Agents are only as effective as the tools we give them. Learn how to write high-quality tools and evaluations, and how you can boost performance by using Claude to optimize its tools for itself.

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) can empower LLM agents with potentially hundreds of tools to solve real-world tasks. But how do we make those tools maximally effective? In this post, we describe our most effective techniques for improving performance in a variety of agentic AI systems.

What You'll Learn

Build and test prototypes

Stand up quick prototypes of your tools and test them locally with Claude Code or Desktop

Create comprehensive evaluations

Run evaluations to measure how well Claude uses your tools with real-world tasks

Collaborate with agents

Use Claude Code to automatically increase the performance of your tools

What is a Tool?

Tools: A New Kind of Software

Tools are software that reflects a contract between deterministic systems and non-deterministic agents. When a user asks "Should I bring an umbrella today?," an agent might call the weather tool, answer from general knowledge, or even ask a clarifying question about location first.

In computing, deterministic systems produce the same output every time given identical inputs, while non-deterministic systems—like agents—can generate varied responses even with the same starting conditions.

This means fundamentally rethinking our approach when writing software for agents: instead of writing tools and MCP servers the way we'd write functions and APIs for other developers or systems, we need to design them for agents.

Our goal is to increase the surface area over which agents can be effective in solving a wide range of tasks by using tools to pursue a variety of successful strategies. The tools that are most "ergonomic" for agents also end up being surprisingly intuitive to grasp as humans.

How to Write Tools

1

Building a Prototype

Stand up a quick prototype of your tools. If you're using Claude Code, give Claude documentation for any software libraries, APIs, or SDKs your tools will rely on. LLM-friendly documentation can commonly be found in flat llms.txt files on official documentation sites.

2

Running an Evaluation

Measure how well Claude uses your tools by running an evaluation. Generate lots of evaluation tasks grounded in real-world uses. Collaborate with an agent to help analyze your results and determine how to improve your tools.

3

Collaborating with Agents

Let agents analyze your results and improve your tools for you. Concatenate the transcripts from your evaluation agents and paste them into Claude Code. Claude is expert at analyzing transcripts and refactoring lots of tools at once.

Generating Strong Evaluation Tasks

Prompts should be inspired by real-world uses and be based on realistic data sources and services. Avoid overly simplistic "sandbox" environments. Strong evaluation tasks might require multiple tool calls—potentially dozens.

Strong Tasks
  • Schedule a meeting with Jane next week to discuss our latest Acme Corp project. Attach the notes from our last project planning meeting and reserve a conference room.
  • Customer ID 9182 reported three charges for a single purchase. Find all relevant log entries and determine if other customers were affected.
  • Customer Sarah Chen submitted a cancellation request. Prepare a retention offer with: (1) why they're leaving, (2) compelling offer, (3) risk factors.
Weak Tasks
  • Schedule a meeting with jane@acme.corp next week.
  • Search the payment logs for purchase_complete and customer_id=9182.
  • Find the cancellation request by Customer ID 45892.

Principles for Writing Effective Tools

Choose the Right Tools

More tools don't always lead to better outcomes. Avoid tools that merely wrap existing API endpoints. Build thoughtful tools targeting specific high-impact workflows.

Namespace Your Tools

Group related tools under common prefixes (e.g., asana_search, jira_search). This helps agents select the right tools at the right time when handling dozens of options.

Return Meaningful Context

Prioritize contextual relevance over flexibility. Eschew low-level identifiers like uuid, 256px_image_url in favor of name, image_url, file_type.

Optimize for Tokens

Implement pagination, range selection, filtering, and truncation. For Claude Code, we restrict tool responses to 25,000 tokens by default.

Tools Should Consolidate Functionality

Examples of Good Tool Consolidation

  • Instead of list_users, list_events, and create_event tools, consider a schedule_event tool which finds availability and schedules an event.
  • Instead of a read_logs tool, consider a search_logs tool which only returns relevant log lines and some surrounding context.
  • Instead of get_customer_by_id, list_transactions, and list_notes tools, implement a get_customer_context tool which compiles all relevant information at once.
LLM agents have limited "context" (limits to how much information they can process at once), whereas computer memory is cheap and abundant. Consider implementing a search_contacts tool instead of a list_contacts tool—the better approach for agents and humans alike is to skip to the relevant page first, rather than reading through each one.

Response Format Flexibility

Agents may require flexibility to interact with both natural language and technical identifiers. You can enable both by exposing a simple response_format enum parameter:

ResponseFormat enum
enum ResponseFormat {
   DETAILED = "detailed",
   CONCISE = "concise"
}
Detailed Response 206 tokens
{
  "thread_ts": "1234567890.123456",
  "channel_id": "C0123456789",
  "user_id": "U0123456789",
  "content": "Let's discuss the Q4 planning...",
  "replies": [...],
  "metadata": {...}
}
Concise Response 72 tokens
{
  "content": "Let's discuss the Q4 planning...",
  "summary": "Thread about Q4 planning with 3 replies"
}

Using concise responses uses ~⅓ of the tokens. IDs can be retrieved from a "detailed" response when needed for further tool calls.

Helpful Error Responses

Unhelpful Error
Error: Invalid parameter
Code: ERR_422
Stack: at validate() line 42...
Helpful Error
Error: date_range exceeds 90 days.
Try: Use pagination with 
start_date and end_date params
to fetch in smaller chunks.

Prompt-Engineering Tool Descriptions

One of the most effective methods for improving tools is prompt-engineering your tool descriptions and specs. These are loaded into your agents' context and can collectively steer agents toward effective tool-calling behaviors.

Best Practices for Tool Descriptions

  • Think like onboarding a new hire: Consider the context you might implicitly bring and make it explicit
  • Define specialized terms: Query formats, niche terminology, relationships between resources
  • Avoid ambiguity: Clearly describe expected inputs and outputs with strict data models
  • Name parameters unambiguously: Instead of user, use user_id
  • Measure with evaluations: Even small refinements can yield dramatic improvements
Claude Sonnet 3.5 achieved state-of-the-art performance on the SWE-bench Verified evaluation after we made precise refinements to tool descriptions, dramatically reducing error rates and improving task completion.

Looking Ahead

To build effective tools for agents, we need to re-orient our software development practices from predictable, deterministic patterns to non-deterministic ones.

Through the iterative, evaluation-driven process we've described in this post, we've identified consistent patterns in what makes tools successful:

  • Effective tools are intentionally and clearly defined
  • They use agent context judiciously
  • They can be combined together in diverse workflows
  • They enable agents to intuitively solve real-world tasks

In the future, we expect the specific mechanisms through which agents interact with the world to evolve—from updates to the MCP protocol to upgrades to the underlying LLMs themselves. With a systematic, evaluation-driven approach to improving tools for agents, we can ensure that as agents become more capable, the tools they use will evolve alongside them.
